newsitem.title: FRANCE: Chirac promises gloomy France more of the same.
newsitem.headline: Chirac promises gloomy France more of the same.

text.p: President Jacques Chirac faced scorn and praise on Friday for promising a gloomy France more of the same painful austerity despite growing popular discontent.

Nineteen months into his seven-year term, he told voters on Thursday night the country needed more "draconian" budget cuts to restore its finances and join the single European currency before it could revive the economy and curb record unemployment.

In a two-hour television interview, the 64-year-old Gaullist president ruled out a devaluation of the franc suggested by government allies to revive growth and said the euro was vital to give Europe the power to challenge U.S. "hegemony".
He ruled out dismissing Prime Minister Alain Juppe and blamed discontent on a conservative society fearful of the future and paralysed by traditions and corporatism.
Predictably his supporters hailed his courage for sticking to his line despite the government's record unpopularity while his foes accused him of doggedly ignoring failure.
Chirac "stuck to a policy that doesn't work," said Socialist Party spokesman Francois Hollande.
Juppe, buoyed by renewed presidential support, said Chirac expressed "a great ambition for a strong, generous and united France".

Analysts had speculated that Chirac would announce a cabinet reshuffle or an early election and voiced disappointment that he had no major announcement in the long-awaited interview, his first major public statement in five months.
"Is that all?" asked the left-leaning daily Liberation, summing up a general feeling in the press that Chirac had no miracle cure for the country's woes.
The pro-government Le Figaro wrote Chirac had given his rule a "second wind". The tabloid Le Parisien called the interview, watched live by more than nine million viewers, "The Big Flop".
Chirac's only new announcement was that he was setting up a commission to reform the judiciary by making state prosecutors independent from the Justice Ministry.
The Magistrates' Union welcomed the plan, which followed charges that the government had ordered prosecutors to drop embarrassing political sleaze probes into close allies of Chirac.

Grilled at length on the probes for the first time since he came to office, Chirac said they must be carried out to the end and "punishment must be all the more exemplary as it concerns people in positions of power."
Rightists applauded the blame placed by Chirac on society's conservatism, but trade unions were enraged by his accusations that they were determined to sink any reform.
"His determination to shake up all avowed or hidden forms of conservatism is the guarantee of success for the country," said Michel Pericard, head of the Gaullist party in the National Assembly.
"He said the French were conservative but they're not. Our political and economic rulers are," said Socialist former culture minister Jack Lang.

"I cannot remember any president taking on the unions so headon," said Marc Blondel, leader of the Workers' Force (FO) union, while Louis Viannet, head of the Communist-led General Labour Confederation (CGT), called the interview "pathetic" and charged Chirac was at a loss for new responses and prospects.
"The French people's fault?" the influential daily Le Monde asked, mocking the president for exposing "the temptation to fire a people that does not deserve such courageous leaders".
